revision.comment: Reverted to revision 869609865 by [[Special:Contributions/2601:541:4500:1760:E5EF:6358:C096:742D|2601:541:4500:1760:E5EF:6358:C096:742D]] ([[User talk:2601:541:4500:1760:E5EF:6358:C096:742D|talk]]): Reverted unhelpful edit. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{short description|United Nations day on 19 November to tackle global sanitation crisis}} {{Redirect|WTD}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = World Toilet Day |type = international |image = World Toilet Day (WTD) logo.jpg |imagesize = |caption = Logo of World Toilet Day |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = worldwide |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = |begins = |ends = |date = 19 November |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = [[UN-Water]] (convener), [[World Toilet Organization]] (initiator) |firsttime = 19 November 2001 (unofficially) and 19 November 2012 (as an official [[United Nations|UN]] Day) }} '''World Toilet Day''' ('''WTD''') is an official [[United Nations]] [[List of international observances|international observance day]] on 19 November to inspire action to tackle the global [[sanitation]] crisis.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/|title=What is World Toilet Day?|last=|first=|date=|website=World Toilet Day|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 November 2017}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/millenniumgoals/pdf/DSG%20sanitation%20two-pager%20FINAL.pdf|title=Call to action on UN website|date=|website=|publisher=|accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref> Worldwide, 4.5 billion people live without "[[Improved sanitation|safely managed sanitation]]"<ref name="JMP2017">WHO and UNICEF (2017) [https://washdata.org/reports Progress on Drinking Water, Sanitation and Hygiene: 2017 Update and SDG Baselines]. Geneva: World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), 2017</ref> and around 892 million people practise open defecation.<ref name="JMP2017" /> [[Sustainable Development Goal 6]] aims to achieve sanitation for all and end open defecation.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/water-and-sanitation/|title=Goal 6: Ensure access to water and sanitation for all|last=|first=|date=|website=United Nations|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 November 2017}}</ref> World Toilet Day exists to inform, engage and inspire people to take action toward achieving this goal.
World Toilet Day was established by the [[World Toilet Organization]] in 2001. Twelve years later, the [[United Nations General Assembly|UN General Assembly]] declared World Toilet Day an official UN day in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/en/events/toiletday/background.shtml|title=World Toilet Day 19 November - Background|last=|first=|date=|website=United Nations|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 November 2017}}</ref>
[[UN-Water]] is the official convener of World Toilet Day. UN-Water maintains the official World Toilet Day website and chooses a special theme for each year. In 2018 the theme is [[nature-based solutions]]. Themes in previous years included [[wastewater]], "toilets and jobs" and "toilets and nutrition".<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9" /> World Toilet Day is marked by communications campaigns and other activities. Events are planned by [[UN entity|UN entities]], international organizations, local [[Non-governmental organization|civil society organizations]] and volunteers to raise awareness and inspire action.
[[Toilet|Toilets]] are important because access to a safe functioning toilet has a positive impact on [[public health]], [[dignity|human dignity]], and personal safety, especially for women.<ref name="autogenerated3" /> Sanitation systems that do not safely treat excreta allow the spread of disease.<ref name="JMP2017" /> Serious [[soil-transmitted helminthiasis|soil-transmitted diseases]] and [[waterborne diseases]] such as [[cholera]], [[diarrhea]], [[Typhoid fever|typhoid]], [[dysentery]] and [[schistosomiasis]] can result.
== Convener == [[File:Urgent Run Germany 2014.jpg|thumb|School children in Germany running the "Urgent Run" to celebrate World Toilet Day 2014]] [[File:World Toilet Day celebrations in Senegal 2014.jpg|thumb|World Toilet Day 2014 "Urgent Run" in Senegal]] [[File:World Toilet Day celebrations in Pakistan 2015.jpg|thumb|Celebrating World Toilet Day 2015 in Pakistan]]
In 2013, [[UN-Water]] and the "Thematic Priority Area (TPA) on Drinking Water and Basic Sanitation" received the mandate to oversee World Toilet Day each year. This mandate is described in the United Nations Resolution A/67/L.75.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/millenniumgoals/pdf/GA%20Sanitation%20for%20All%20resolution%2024%20July.pdf|title=UN resolution A/67/L.75|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=22 August 2015}}</ref>
In consultation with the UN-Water World Toilet Day Task Force, made up of UN-Water member organizations, UN-Water selects the theme based on that year's [[UN World Water Development Report|World Water Development Report]] and develops content for World Toilet Day communications campaigns.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unwater.org/what-we-do/inspire-action/|title=UN-Water’s Campaigns|last=|first=|date=|website=UN-Water (United Nations)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 November 2018}}</ref>
UN-Water manages the World Toilet Day website which promotes key issues and stories, provides communications and campaigns resources, and announces events and opportunities to participate.<ref name=":10" />
The overall World Toilet Day campaign mobilizes civil society, think tanks, [[non-governmental organizations]], academics, corporations and the general public to participate in the associated social media and communications campaigns.<ref name=":11" /> Ultimately, the aim is to encourage organizations and governments to plan activities and action on [[sanitation]] issues to make progress on [[Sustainable Development Goal 6]].<ref name=":10" />
== Themes == [[File:World Toilet Day celebrations in Singapore 2016.jpg|thumb|Leading "The Big Squat" during the [[Singapore]] "Urgent Run" 2016 is [[Jack Sim]], front row left, founder of [[World Toilet Organization]].]] Starting in 2012, World Toilet Day themes were selected for each year and form the basis of the related communications campaigns. Since 2016, the same overall annual theme has been used for both World Toilet Day and [[World Water Day]], based on the [[UN World Water Development Report|World Water Development Report]]. *2012 – "I give a shit, do you?" (slogan) <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/international/21567057-every-cause-has-its-day-whether-deserved-or-not-dies-irae|title=Dies irae|date=24 November 2012|work=The Economist}}</ref> * 2013 – Tourism and Water: Protecting our Common Future * 2014 – [[social equality|Equality]] and [[Dignity]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2014/nov/20/world-toilet-day-yuck|title=World Toilet Day. Yuck!|last=Gjersoe|first=Nathalia|date=20 November 2014|work=The Guardian|access-date=10 August 2015|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/2014|title=World Toilet Day website 2014|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * 2015 – Toilets and Nutrition<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/2015/about/|title=World Toilet Day Website - About (2015)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 October 2018}}</ref> * 2016 – Toilets and Jobs<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/2016|title=World Toilet Day website 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":8">UN-Water (2016) [http://www.unwater.org/publications/world-water-development-report-2016/ World Water Development Report 2016: Water and jobs], Geneva, Switzerland</ref> * 2017 – [[Wastewater]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/2017/theme/|title=World Toilet Day Website - Theme (2017)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 October 2018}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.unwater.org/publications/world-water-development-report-2017/|title=World Water Development Report 2017|website=UN-Water|language=en-US|access-date=12 November 2018}}</ref> *2018 – [[Nature-based solutions]] (slogan: "When Nature calls")<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/wtd2018/|title=World Toilet Day 2018|last=|first=|date=|website=UN-Water|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=27 September 2018}}</ref><ref>UN-Water (2018) [http://www.unwater.org/publications/world-water-development-report-2018/ World Water Development Report 2018: Nature-based Solutions for Water], Geneva, Switzerland</ref>
== Examples of activities and events ==
=== Urgent Run ===
In the lead-up to World Toilet Day, communities worldwide come together for sanitation-themed "Urgent Runs". More than 63 events were held in 42 countries. Events included fun runs, awareness walks, toilet cleaning programs, carnivals and even motorbike parades.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://urgentrun.com/why.php|title=What's the urgency?|last=|first=|date=|website=The Urgent Run|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 November 2017}}</ref> Organizers unite communities around the world to raise awareness of the global sanitation challenge and engage people with sanitation issues in their local communities.<ref name=":2" /> Community groups, private companies, universities and NGOs plan events all over the world. Countries participating include: Bangladesh, Benin, Bhutan, Burundi, Cambodia, Cameroon, Canada, China, Congo-Brazzaville, France, Gambia, Germany, Ghana, India,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsgram.com/the-urgent-run-to-address-sanitation-problem-in-delhi/|title=The Urgent Run to address sanitation problems in Delhi|last=|first=|date=2 November 2015|work=NewsGram|access-date=13 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Indonesia, Italy, Kenya, Mongolia, Mozambique, Namibia, Netherlands, Pakistan, Philippines, Senegal, Tanzania, United States and Vietnam.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://giaoduc.net.vn/Giao-duc-24h/Hon-2000-ban-tre-chay-khan-cap-vi-nha-ve-sinh-sach-post163375.gd|title=More than 2,000 young people run urgently because of clean toilets|last=|first=|date=15 November 2015|work=Electronic newspaper Vietnam Education|access-date=13 April 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref name=":2" />
=== Launch of reports === Some organizations launch [[toilet]]-related (or sanitation-related) reports on World Toilet Day. For example: * WHO, UNICEF and [[United States Agency for International Development|USAID]] (2015) "Improving Nutrition Outcomes with Better Water, Sanitation and Hygiene: Practical Solutions for Policies and Programmes"<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/193991/1/9789241565103_eng.pdf|title=Improving nutrition outcomes with better water, sanitation and hygiene: practical solutions for policies and programmes. 1.Nutrition Disorders – etiology. 2.Water Quality. 3.Sanitation. 4.Hygiene. Health. 5.Knowledge, Attitudes, Practice|last=|first=|publisher=World Health Organization, UNICEF, USAID|year=2015|isbn=978 92 4 156510 3|location=|pages=}}</ref> * The [[International Labour Organization|International Labour Office]] (ILO) (2016) "WASH@Work: self-training handbook<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldtoilet.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/ILO-Wash@Work-Toolkit.pdf|title=WASH@Work: a Self-Training Handbook|last=|first=|publisher=International Labour Office|year=2016|isbn=9789221285236|location=Geneva|pages=}}</ref> * The Toilet Board Coalition (2017) "Sanitation Economy"<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.toiletboard.org/media/30-Sanitation_Economy_Final.pdf|title=Introducing the Sanitation Economy|last=|first=|publisher=Toilet Board Coalition|year=2017|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> * Water and Sanitation for the Urban Poor (WSUP) (2017) "Guide to strengthening the enabling environment for [[Fecal sludge management|faecal sludge management]]"<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsup.com/insights/a-guide-to-strengthening-the-enabling-environment-for-faecal-sludge-management/|title=Guide to strengthening the enabling environment for faecal sludge management|last=|first=|date=17 November 2017|website=Water and Sanitation for the Urban Poor|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=17 November 2017}}</ref>
=== Public education === Members of the [[Sustainable Sanitation Alliance]] (SuSanA) used the momentum around World Toilet Day in 2017 to update [[Wikipedia]] articles on [[WASH]]-related topics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/meet-up-on-wikipedia/|title=Meet up on Wikipedia!|last=|first=|date=|website=World Toilet Day (UN Water)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 November 2017}}</ref> This contributes to public education about the sanitation crisis.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sei-international.org/press/press-releases/3771|title=Join the SuSanA Sanitation Wikipedia project|last=|first=|date=10 October 2017|website=Stockholm Environment Institute (SEI)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=9 November 2017}}</ref>
The documentary "Follow the Flush," released 19 November 2017, educates people about what happens beneath the streets of [[New York City]] after a person flushes a toilet in Manhattan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thepoopproject.org/flush-watch|title=Follow the Flush|last=Mangu-Ward|first=Karina|date=16 November 2017|website=The Poop Project|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 November 2017}}</ref>
=== 2018 events === Planned events for World Toilet Day 2018 include diverse activities such as a '[[hackathon]]' in Ghana to promote digital solutions<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/wtd2018/event/sanitation-hackathon/|title=World Toilet Day Hackathon|last=|first=|date=|website=UN Water|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 November 2018}}</ref>, a seminar hosted by [[Engineers Without Borders (Denmark)|Engineers without Borders]] in Denmark<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/wtd2018/event/celebrate-world-toilet-day-with-engineers-without-borders-denmark-and-water-dtu/|title=Open seminar by Engineers without boarders|last=|first=|date=|website=UN Water|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 November 2018}}</ref>, a screening and discussion of the [[Bollywood]] movie [[Toilet: Ek Prem Katha]] (in English - ''Toilet: A Love Story'') in Canada<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/wtd2018/event/world-toilet-day-at-waterloo-film-screening/|title=Film screening Toilet: a love story|last=|first=|date=|website=UN Water|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 November 2018}}</ref>, and a school drawing competition in India<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/wtd2018/event/draw-a-world-without-toilets/|title=Draw a world without toilets, India |last=|first=|date=|website=UN Water|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 November 2018}}</ref>.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldtoiletday.info/wtd2018/events/|title=World Toilet Day 2018 Events|last=|first=|date=|website=UN Water|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 November 2018}}</ref>
==Impacts== In 2016, the World Toilet Day campaign and related publications reached millions of people through [[social media]], dedicated websites and other channels.<ref name="UNWater2016">{{Cite book|url=http://www.unwater.org/publications/un-water-annual-report-2016/|title=Annual Report UN-Water 2016|last=|first=|publisher=UN-Water|year=2016|isbn=|location=Geneva, Switzerland|pages=}}</ref>{{rp|21}} Over 100 events in 40 countries were registered on the World Toilet Day website in both 2016 and in 2017.<ref name="UNWater2016" />{{rp|23}}<ref name="UNWater2017" />{{rp|17}} The UN-Water Annual Report states that in 2017 the hashtag #WorldToiletDay had a maximum potential reach of around 750 million people on social media.<ref name="UNWater2017">{{Cite book|url=http://www.unwater.org/publications/un-water-annual-report-2017/|title=Annual Report UN-Water 2017|last=|first=|publisher=UN-Water|year=2017|isbn=|location=Geneva, Switzerland|pages=}}</ref>{{rp|17}}
== History == [[File:2013 World Toilet Day at United Nations, New York.jpg|thumb|World Toilet Day officially declared in 2013 at the 67th session of the [[UN general assembly|UN General Assembly]] in New York.]]
On 19 November 2001, the [[World Toilet Organization]] (WTO) was founded by [[Jack Sim]], a [[Philanthropy|philanthropist]] from [[Singapore]]. He subsequently declared 19 November as World Toilet Day.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/11/19/dont-laugh-world-toilet-day-aims-to-promote-sanitation-rid-world-disease.html|title=Don't Laugh: World Toilet Day Aims to Promote Sanitation, Rid World of Disease|date=19 November 2008|work=Fox News}}</ref>
The WTO later the UN chose the name "World Toilet Day" and not "World Sanitation Day" for ease of public messaging. In fact, toilets are only the first stage of sanitation systems.<ref name="tilley">{{cite book|url=http://www.eawag.ch/en/department/sandec/publications/compendium/|title=Compendium of Sanitation Systems and Technologies|last1=Tilley|first1=Elizabeth|last2=Ulrich|first2=Lukas|last3=Lüthi|first3=Christoph|last4=Reymond|first4=Philippe|last5=Zurbrügg|first5=Chris|publisher=Swiss Federal Institute of Aquatic Science and Technology (Eawag)|isbn=978-3-906484-57-0|edition=2nd|location=Duebendorf, Switzerland}}</ref> World Toilet Day events and public awareness campaigns increase public awareness of the broader sanitation systems that include [[wastewater treatment]], [[fecal sludge management]], [[municipal solid waste]] management, [[stormwater]] management, [[hygiene]], and [[handwashing]]. Also, the UN [[Sustainable Development Goals]] call for more than just toilets. [[Sustainable Development Goal 6|Goal 6]] calls for adequate sanitation, which includes the whole system for assuring that waste is safely processed.<ref name=":0" />
The WTO began pushing for global recognition for World Toilet Day and, in 2007, the [[Sustainable Sanitation Alliance]] (SuSanA) began to actively support World Toilet Day, too.<ref>Gröber, K., McCreary, C., Kappauf, L., Panzerbieter, T., Rück, J. (2012). [http://www.susana.org/en/resources/library/details/749 Public awareness raising and sanitation marketing – Factsheet of Working Group 9b]. Sustainable Sanitation Alliance (SuSanA)</ref> Their efforts to raise attention for the sanitation crisis were bolstered in 2010 when the [[human right to water and sanitation]] was officially declared a [[human right]] by the UN.<ref name=":5" />
In 2013, a joint initiative between the [[Government of Singapore]] and the World Toilet Organization led to Singapore's first UN resolution, named "Sanitation for All". The resolution calls for collective action to end the world's sanitation crisis. World Toilet Day was declared an official UN day in 2013. That resolution was adopted by 122 countries at the 67th session of the [[United Nations General Assembly|UN General Assembly]] in New York.<ref>World Toilet Organisation: [http://worldtoilet.org/what-we-do/world-toilet-day/ World Toilet Day]. Retrieved 5 August 2015.</ref>
The [[Sustainable Development Goals]] (SDGs) replaced the [[Millennium Development Goals]] (MDGs) in 2016. On World Toilet Day on 19 November 2015, United Nations Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] urged broad action to renew efforts to provide access to adequate sanitation for all. He reminded everyone of the "Call to Action on Sanitation" which was launched in 2013, and the aim to end [[open defecation]] by 2025.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=52596#.WguEy1T9SUl|title=Marking World Toilet Day, UN urges ‘open, frank’ discussion on importance of hygiene and sanitation|last=|first=|date=19 November 2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 November 2017}}</ref> He also said: “By many accounts, sanitation is the most-missed target of the Millennium Development Goals."<ref name=":3" />
The UN Deputy Secretary-General, [[Jan Eliasson]], was honored on World Toilet Day in 2016 in New York for his deep commitment to breaking the sanitation [[taboo]].<ref name="UNWater2016" />{{rp|23}} For example, he had delivered a video message to attendees of a [[WaterAid]] and [[Unilever]] joint event in the [[European Parliament]] on World Toilet Day 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QU9NE6aXutc|title=A message from the UN Deputy Secretary-General on World Toilet Day 2014|last=|first=|date=17 November 2014|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 November 2017}}</ref> In 2016, UN-Water supported “A Toast for Toilets” in New York with the United Nations Mission of Singapore.<ref name="UNWater2016" />{{rp|23}}
==Background== {{Main|Sanitation|Open defecation|Toilet|WASH}} [[File:Child in open sewer in Nigeria (3150664698).jpg|thumb| Child defecating in a canal in the slum of Gege in the city of [[Ibadan]], Nigeria]]
Worldwide, 4.5 billion people live without "[[Improved sanitation|safely managed sanitation]]".<ref name="JMP2017" /> Around 892 million people worldwide practise [[open defecation]]. Of those, 678 million live in just seven countries. [[India]] has the highest number of people (about 525 million) practising open defecation.<ref name="JMP2017" /> Having to defecate in the open is especially difficult for women and girls. Women tend to resort to the cover of darkness to give them more privacy, but then risk being attacked when alone at night.<ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite web|last1=Cavill|first1=Sue|title=Violence, gender and WASH: A practitioner's toolkit: Making Water, Sanitation and hygiene safer through improved programming and services|url=http://violence-wash.lboro.ac.uk/|publisher=WaterAid, SHARE Research Consortium|access-date=7 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite journal|last1=Lennon|first1=Shirley|title=Fear and anger: Perceptions of risks related to sexual violence against women linked to water and sanitation in Delhi, India|journal=SHARE (Sanitation and Hygiene Applied Research for Equity) and WaterAid, UK|date=November 2011|url=http://www.susana.org/en/resources/library/details/1758|access-date=7 October 2015}}</ref>
It has been estimated that 58% of all cases of [[diarrhea]] worldwide in 2015 were caused by unsafe water, poor sanitation and poor hygiene practices, such as inadequate [[handwashing]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Burden of disease from inadequate water, sanitation and hygiene in low- and middle-income settings: a retrospective analysis of data from 145 countries|date=2014|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/tmi.12329/abstract|journal=Tropical Medicine|volume=19|pages=894–905|doi=10.1111/tmi.12329|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> This resulted in half a million children under the age of five dying from diarrhea per year.<ref name=":4">{{Citation|title=UNICEF: Ending Child Deaths from Pneumonia and Diarrhoea|date=2015|url=https://data.unicef.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Pneumonia_Diarrhoea_brochure.pdf|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref> Providing sanitation has been estimated to lower the odds of children suffering diarrhea by 7–17%, and under-five mortality by 5–20%.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gunther|first1=Isabel|last2=Fink|first2=Gunther|date=April 2010|title=Water, Sanitation and Children’s Health Evidence from 172 DHS Surveys|url=https://sanitationupdates.files.wordpress.com/2010/05/worldbank-dhs2010.pdf|journal=The World Bank Development Economics Prospects Group|issue=5275|accessdate=7 October 2015}}</ref>
The [[Human right to water and sanitation|Human Right to Water and Sanitation]] was recognized as a [[human right]] by the [[United Nations General Assembly|United Nations (UN) General Assembly]] on 28 July 2010. Lack of access to [[sanitation]] (toilets) has an impact on [[public health]], [[dignity]], and safety.<ref name="autogenerated3" /> The spread of many diseases (e.g. [[soil-transmitted helminthiasis]], [[diarrhea]], [[schistosomiasis]]) and [[stunted growth]] in children is directly related to people being exposed to [[human feces]] because toilets are either not available or not used.
[[Sustainable Development Goal 6]] aims to provide sanitation for all.<ref name="JMP2017" />
